pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

content.raw:
`convert_function` is deprecated.  It shouldn't be necessary so long as you supply the correct units.

For this one you should just fold the constant conversion into the `_OVI_NumberDensity` field.  I would also change the field name to match our naming convention: "OVI_number_density".
content.html:
convert_function is deprecated. It shouldn't be necessary so long as you supply the correct units.

For this one you should just fold the constant conversion into the _OVI_NumberDensity field. I would also change the field name to match our naming convention: "OVI_number_density".

pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

content.raw: It doesn't seem like the best use of time for developers to indicate how to fix various recipes in this PR, and then have me go and apply their fixes as part of this PR.  I think a better solution would be to check this PR for major mistakes, and then iterate on this after it is accepted, where developers who know how to fix certain recipes go and fix those recipes as additional PRs.  As noted above, all of the problems holding back specific recipes are noted on the yt 3.0 trello board.
content.html: It doesn't seem like the best use of time for developers to indicate how to fix various recipes in this PR, and then have me go and apply their fixes as part of this PR. I think a better solution would be to check this PR for major mistakes, and then iterate on this after it is accepted, where developers who know how to fix certain recipes go and fix those recipes as additional PRs. As noted above, all of the problems holding back specific recipes are noted on the yt 3.0 trello board.

pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

content.raw:
There's a bug in matplotlib 1.3.1 that prevents it from being able to directly plot ndarray subclasses.  You'll need to cast the data to ndarray before creating the plot.

This will be fixed in matplotlib 1.4.
content.html:
There's a bug in matplotlib 1.3.1 that prevents it from being able to directly plot ndarray subclasses. You'll need to cast the data to ndarray before creating the plot.

This will be fixed in matplotlib 1.4.

pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

content.raw:
For this one you need to cast `new_field` to YTArray.

You could do something like:

```
new_field = np.zeros(data["gravitational_potential"].shape,
                         dtype='float64')*gx.unit_array
```

If you want to be less clear but more concise you could use `gx.ua`, which is an alias for `gx.unit_array`.
content.html:
For this one you need to cast new_field to YTArray.

You could do something like:

new_field = np.zeros(data["gravitational_potential"].shape,
                         dtype='float64')*gx.unit_array

If you want to be less clear but more concise you could use gx.ua, which is an alias for gx.unit_array.

pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)
Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

content.raw:
You can't pass YTArray instances to matplotlib, in most cases.

In this example `frb['density']` and `frb['temperature']` need to be converted.  You can do that in four entirely equivalent ways:


```
#!python

ytarray = frb['density']
a1 = np.array(ytarray)
a2 = ytarray.to_ndarray()
a3 = ytarray.value
a4 = ytarray.v
```

See: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/data_selection_and_fields.html#Working-with-views-and-converting-to-ndarray
content.html:
You can't pass YTArray instances to matplotlib, in most cases.

In this example frb['density'] and frb['temperature'] need to be converted. You can do that in four entirely equivalent ways:

ytarray = frb['density']
a1 = np.array(ytarray)
a2 = ytarray.to_ndarray()
a3 = ytarray.value
a4 = ytarray.v

See: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/analyzing/units/data_selection_and_fields.html#Working-with-views-and-converting-to-ndarray

Yeah, it will be fixed in matplotlib 1.4.  There won't be a matplotlib 1.3.2 unfortunately.

See:

https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/2591

https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/2290

Particularly the discussion on the second pull request.

pullrequest.title: Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)
Updating 3.0 cookbook recipes (and some bug fixes)

description:
I've gone through all of the cookbook recipes and tested if they work in yt 3.0.  I've updated them all to use the standards of 3.0 (e.g. pf -> ds, pf.h -> ds, from yt.mods import * -> import yt, etc.).  

I've also tried to identify what is wrong in each of the recipes that fail and correct the bug responsible.  Unfortunately, there are still a lot of problems that are beyond my ability right now to fix.  Thus, I've marked a line at the top of each recipe that fails (either fails to run, or fails to give the right answer) with a comment telling the user that the recipe is broken and not to trust it in 3.0.

Along with this PR, I'm updating the trello board for yt-3.0 ( https://trello.com/b/Y5XV4Hod/yt-3-0 ) in the cookbook section with the status of each recipe.

UPDATE1: Corrected to take into account @ngoldbaum 's suggestions.  Also updated trello board.
